stem: Click to highlight the findings that require immediate notification to the healthcare provider.
passage: A 3-year-old client with suspected Kawasaki Disease presents with a persistent fever. The nurse notes [a maculopapular rash on the trunk], [strawberry tongue], and [bilateral conjunctival injection without exudate]. The vital signs show [BP 90/60], [HR 160 bpm], [RR 36], and [temperature 103.5°F (39.7°C)]. The client is also exhibiting [irritability] and [refusal to eat].

tabs.title: Nurses' Notes
tabs.content: 07:00: Received report from night shift. 3-year-old male admitted for suspected Kawasaki Disease. Noted persistent fever for 5 days, unresponsive to antipyretics. 07:15: Assessed patient. Noted maculopapular rash on trunk, strawberry tongue, and bilateral conjunctival injection without exudate. Patient is irritable and refusing to eat. 07:30: Vital signs obtained: BP 90/60, HR 160 bpm, RR 36, Temp 103.5°F (39.7°C). Oxygen saturation 96% on room air. 07:45: Contacted physician regarding findings. Orders received and initiated. Will continue to monitor vital signs and patient condition closely. Educated parents on Kawasaki Disease and treatment plan.

tabs.title: Physical Exam
tabs.content:
• General: Irritable, inconsolable
  • Skin: Maculopapular rash on trunk
  • Mouth: Strawberry tongue, red cracked lips
  • Eyes: Bilateral conjunctival injection without exudate
  • Cardiovascular: Tachycardia, no murmurs
  • Respiratory: Increased respiratory rate, clear lung sounds

tabs.title: Care Plan
tabs.content:
• IVIG infusion over 10-12 hours
  • Aspirin 80 mg/kg/day divided q6h
  • Monitor vital signs q1h
  • Strict I&O
  • Cardiac monitoring

rationale.correct: Kawasaki disease is an acute systemic vasculitis of unknown etiology that primarily affects children. Prompt recognition and treatment are essential to prevent serious complications, particularly coronary artery aneurysms. Strawberry tongue, persistent high fever, and hypotension are key indicators requiring immediate intervention.
rationale.incorrect: While a maculopapular rash, conjunctival injection, irritability, and refusal to eat are common symptoms of Kawasaki disease, they are less specific and do not independently warrant the same level of immediate concern as strawberry tongue, persistent fever, and hypotension. These findings should be documented and monitored, but the presence of the highlighted findings necessitates urgent action.

answerBreakdown.label: strawberry tongue
answerBreakdown.content: Strawberry tongue (erythema and prominent papillae) is a classic sign of Kawasaki disease and indicates inflammation of the oral mucosa. This finding, along with fever, is a key diagnostic criterion.

answerBreakdown.label: temperature 103.5°F (39.7°C)
answerBreakdown.content: A persistent high fever (typically >100.4°F or 38°C) for at least 5 days is a hallmark of Kawasaki disease and is often unresponsive to antipyretics. This warrants immediate notification.

answerBreakdown.label: BP 90/60
answerBreakdown.content: Hypotension can occur due to systemic inflammation and vasodilation in Kawasaki disease. Blood pressure should be immediately addressed.

answerBreakdown.label: a maculopapular rash on the trunk
answerBreakdown.content: A maculopapular rash is a common but non-specific finding in Kawasaki disease. It is not as indicative of the disease as other findings.

answerBreakdown.label: bilateral conjunctival injection without exudate
answerBreakdown.content: Bilateral conjunctival injection without exudate is a characteristic feature of Kawasaki disease, but it is not as critical as the presence of fever or strawberry tongue in determining the immediate need for intervention.

answerBreakdown.label: HR 160 bpm
answerBreakdown.content: Tachycardia is a common finding in Kawasaki disease, but in the context of fever and other symptoms, it is not the most critical finding requiring immediate notification. The other findings are more specific and indicative of the need for immediate intervention.

clinicalPearls: Kawasaki disease is a leading cause of acquired heart disease in children.
Early diagnosis and treatment with IVIG and aspirin are crucial to prevent coronary artery aneurysms.
Monitor for signs of heart failure, such as increased heart rate, respiratory distress, and edema.

questionTrap.trap: Focusing solely on the presence of fever without considering other clinical signs can lead to a missed diagnosis of Kawasaki disease. Conversely, attributing every fever to Kawasaki disease without evaluating for other potential causes can result in unnecessary interventions.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Prioritize recognizing the constellation of symptoms associated with Kawasaki disease, including fever, rash, mucositis, extremity changes, and cervical lymphadenopathy. Use a systematic approach to assessment and consider alternative diagnoses if the clinical picture is not consistent with Kawasaki disease.

mnemonic.title: CRASH and BURN
mnemonic.expansion: Conjunctivitis, Rash, Adenopathy, Strawberry tongue, Hand/foot edema, and BURN (fever)
